mn89:6.1: “But great king, for what reason do you demonstrate such utmost devotion for this body, conveying your manifest love?”
mn89:6.2: “Sir, I infer about the Buddha from the teaching:
mn89:6.3: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The Dharma is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
mn89:6.4: It happens, sir, that I see some ascetics and brahmins leading the spiritual life only for a limited period: ten, twenty, thirty, or forty years.
mn89:6.5: Some time later—nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed—they amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn89:6.6: But here I see the mendicants leading the spiritual life entirely full and pure as long as they live, to their last breath.
mn89:6.7: I don’t see any other spiritual life elsewhere so full and pure.
mn89:6.8: That’s why I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:
mn89:6.9: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The Dharma is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
mn89:7.1: Furthermore, kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, householders fight with householders. mn89:7.5: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The Dharma is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
